name: Area of a Circle
explanation: The area of a circle is π (pi, approximately 3.14159) times the square of the radius. The radius is the distance from the center to any point on the circle. This formula shows that area grows quadratically with radius—doubling the radius quadruples the area. π is an irrational number representing the ratio of a circle's circumference to its diameter.

examples.problem: Find the area of a circle with radius 5 cm
A circle has diameter 12. Find its area
examples.solution: 36π square units or approximately 113.10 square units

proof: A = πr². Proof: Divide circle into many thin rings. Ring at radius r has width dr, area ≈ 2πr dr. Total area = ∫[0 to R] 2πr dr = πr²|₀ᴿ = πR². Alternatively, unroll circle into triangle with base 2πr and height r, area = ½(2πr)(r) = πr².
